Elizabeth from Brick said, "I am an 83 year old senior who relies on USPS for delivery of my prescriptions. A delay in my service can be potentially life threatening."
Christine from Berkeley Township said, "I rely on the Postal Service to get the prescriptions I need, especially during the coronavirus pandemic."

Alice Claire from Beachwood said, "I depend on my Social Security Retirement and Federal Retirement check mailed from different areas in the USA.  In addition my financial institution is the Pentagon Federal Credit Union which I depend on, contacting by USPS."

Pat from Waretown said, "For more than 10 years my husband and I have relied on the USPS to deliver our prescription drugs on time. With the monkey business going on now, we have no assurance that medications mailed by our prescription plan will be received in a timely manner."

Joan from Pine Beach said, "I recently had to reschedule a doctor appointment because my medical records hadn't arrived in time for the appointment. The idea, intent and implementation of actions to thwart the mail is disheartening and scary and down right un-American."

Signs of a natural gas leak:

– An odor similar to rotten eggs or a skunk

– Blowing dirt, bubbles, or killed vegetation

– An area of frost on the ground in warm weather if it leaks from an underground pipe

– A quiet hiss or loud roar

#IA01 #derecho2020

During #derecho2020 recovery, it's incredibly important to stay alert for natural gas leaks. If you notice these signs, leave the area immediately and report signs of a leak. #IA01

As we continue to work to overcome the implications of #COVID19, we must look at all ways to improve investment & development opportunities. Ultimately, more economic development by and for Indian tribes & Alaska Native corporations means more economic success for all Americans.

Alongside @SenDanSullivan & @RepDonYoung, I've introduced legislation to make TED Bonds more accessible for the economic development projects of American Indians and Alaska Natives by adjusting the existing tax code and increasing the national volume cap. https://www.murkowski.senate.gov/press/release/alaska-congressional-delegation-introduces-legislation-to-support-economic-development-for-alaska-native-communities
Unfortunately, the limitations currently in place regarding the use of TED bonds hinder a number of opportunities for development in Alaska and across the nation. This must change.

The original intent of Tribal Economic Development Bonds (TED Bonds) was to allow Indian Tribal Governments to finance projects critical to community development. This includes projects such as solid-waste and water treatment facilities, certain residential projects, and more.
